screen_desc: The screenshot shows the settings menu on an Android device. It includes options like "Screen lock, fingerprint," "Accounts," "Accessibility" (for screen readers and display adjustments), "Google" (for services and preferences), "System" (for languages, gestures, time, and backup), and "About emulated device" (detailing the Android SDK for x86). These are all settings categories for managing various aspects of the phone. The bottom shows navigation buttons for back, home, and recent apps.
action_think: The user has requested to change the keyboard looks. The current screen shows the settings menu, but there's no direct option visible for keyboard settings. Based on the visible settings categories, the most logical next step is to go into 'System' settings, which could contain language and input options, including keyboard settings.
action_plan: Click on 'System' to access further settings where the keyboard settings are likely to be found.

action_result:
By clicking on the "System" option in the last action, the settings menu for system-related features has been opened. Now, in the current screenshot, you can see options related to languages, gestures, date & time, backup, and advanced settings, including "Languages & input." This is an important step toward fulfilling the user request, as changing the keyboard's appearance usually involves going into the "Languages & input" settings. 

This action has made progress toward completing the user request because it has opened the section of the settings where you can manage input methods, which is where the option to change the keyboard look will likely be found. The next step would be selecting the "Languages & input" option to modify the keyboard's settings.
